about.title: About
about.subtitle: A bit about who I am and what I enjoy working on.
about.intro_p1: I'm a technology consultant who enjoys turning ambiguous problems into clear, user‚Äëcentered solutions. Over the past few years, I've worked across banking and retail, helping teams modernize their systems, improve customer experiences, and ship reliable products.
about.intro_p2: My work usually sits at the intersection of business analysis, product thinking, and engineering ‚Äî from mapping out future‚Äëstate architectures to building lightweight tools that automate away repetitive work.
about.what_i_do_desc: Bridge business needs and technical teams to design and deliver practical digital solutions.
about.what_i_care_desc: Build thoughtful systems and experiences that actually benefit the people using them.
about.hobby_climbing_desc: Finding new routes, solving movement puzzles, and enjoying time on the wall.
about.hobby_photo_desc: Taking photos of everyday scenes, friends, and trips to document life as it happens.
about.hobby_running_desc: Short city runs to reset, think through ideas, and stay active between projects.
about.hobby_building_desc: Experimenting with small tools and prototypes to try new tech and deploy ideas quickly.

post1.title: The AI Agent Hype vs. Reality: A Practitioner's Guide for 2026
post1.excerpt: Cut through the noise and understand what AI agents can actually deliver. Real examples of successes, failures, and a practical framework for evaluation.
post1.author: üë§ Gary Yong

content.intro1: Last week, I saw an ad claiming AI agents could "replace 20 employees overnight." On platforms like Moltbook‚Äîa social network where AI bots interact autonomously‚Äîpeople are posting about agents "starting religions" and developing their own thoughts. Meanwhile, my inbox is flooded with pitches for "revolutionary AI workforce solutions."
content.intro2: Sound familiar? Welcome to 2026's AI agent gold rush.
content.intro3: As someone who's spent years implementing AI solutions across enterprise environments, I've witnessed both spectacular successes and spectacular failures. Here's what I've learned about separating hype from reality.
content.section1_p1: Let's start with a success story. I recently worked with a major bank deploying Google's conversational AI for their contact center. The system combines voice bots with real-time speech analytics‚Äîand the results were impressive: 40% reduction in call resolution time and measurably improved customer satisfaction.
content.section1_p2: The key to their success? They didn't try to replace humans‚Äîthey augmented them.
content.section1_p3: The AI handles routine inquiries (balance checks, transaction history, basic troubleshooting) while seamlessly escalating complex issues to human agents with full context. Speech analytics identifies customer sentiment in real-time, helping agents adjust their approach mid-conversation.
content.section1_p4: This isn't flashy disruption. It's practical, measurable improvement that directly impacts both the bottom line and customer experience.
content.section2_p1: Not every implementation succeeds. I've observed a consistent pattern: systems work beautifully in controlled testing, then fall apart when they encounter the messy exceptions that define real business operations.
content.section2_p2: The failures typically stem from three root causes:
section2_bullets: Misaligned expectations: Organizations expect AI agents to handle every edge case and understand context like humans. When reality falls short of these expectations, disappointment follows.

Rigid AI in flexible environments: AI excels at consistency, but many business processes require flexibility and judgment. Forcing rigid automation onto inherently flexible processes creates frustration for everyone.

Poor data quality: This is the silent killer. Fragmented, inconsistent data doesn't just reduce accuracy‚Äîit can stall projects entirely. Clean, structured data isn't optional; it's the foundation everything else is built on.
content.section3_p1: Before greenlighting any AI agent project, I ask three questions:
section3_list: Is this genuinely repetitive? If there's significant variation or creativity required, human oversight remains essential.
How sensitive is the data? High-sensitivity environments need additional safeguards and human checkpoints. Security can't be an afterthought.
What does success look like‚Äîspecifically? Vague goals like "improve efficiency" aren't enough. You need measurable KPIs everyone agrees on before development begins.
content.section3_p2: These questions eliminate about 60% of problematic projects before they start.
content.section3_p3: For implementations already underway, I apply three litmus tests: consistency (same input, same output every time), graceful human handoff (seamless escalation when the AI hits its limits), and real-world performance (results outside controlled testing).
content.section4_p1: Despite the hype, real progress is happening. The developments I'm most excited about:
content.section4_p2: Proactive task management: Agents that anticipate needs rather than just responding to requests‚Äîscheduling meetings based on email context, flagging potential issues before they become problems, managing workflows across systems.
content.section4_p3: Persistent memory and learning: We're moving from reactive systems to assistants that remember context and adapt over time. The next 12-18 months will bring more powerful models with better tool integration and genuine learning capabilities.
content.section4_quote: The AI agent revolution is real‚Äîbut it's about augmenting human capabilities, not replacing humans wholesale.
content.section5_p1: If you're evaluating AI agents for your organization, here's my advice:
content.section5_p2: Start small. Target your most repetitive tasks with clear success metrics. Don't try to automate everything at once.
content.section5_p3: Invest in data quality. The organizations that will succeed are those building the infrastructure to support sophisticated AI systems. That starts with clean, structured data.
content.section5_p4: Design for humans. The best implementations enhance human capabilities rather than replacing them. Build in oversight, intervention points, and graceful fallbacks.
content.section5_p5: The companies that understand the distinction between hype and reality‚Äîand implement AI agents accordingly‚Äîwill thrive. Those chasing headlines without understanding fundamentals will waste time, money, and opportunity.
content.cta_question: What's your experience with AI agents?
content.cta_text: I'd love to hear your stories. Connect with me on LinkedIn to continue the conversation.

ask_gary.title: Ask Gary
ask_gary.subtitle: Personal AI Career Agent
ask_gary.welcome_p1: Hi! I'm Ask Gary, Gary's career assistant. I'm here to answer questions about his professional background, skills, projects, and experiences on his behalf.
ask_gary.welcome_p2: Feel free to ask me anything‚Äîfor example: "What did Gary do at Capco?" or "Tell me about Gary's experience with AI and automation."

ask_gary.question_2: "Summarize Gary's experience with AI and automation."
ask_gary.how_1: Answers are grounded only in Gary's resumes and career docs.
ask_gary.how_2: Top‚ÄëK relevant chunks are retrieved for each question.
ask_gary.how_3: The model is instructed to say "I don't know" when context is missing.
